reviewText: A lot of horror movies this past decade were extremely formulaic, boring, and don't break any mold whatsoever, but "Orphan" is surprisingly a break from all of those forgettable horror films. It has a great setting along with a great atmosphere (winter is a great time to shoot a horror film), and the cinematography is also amazing. The plot line seems like something that's been done before, but it was used in a great way."Orphan" has great acting and amazing drama that makes the film hard to forget, because it is one of the standout films of 2009. For anybody who doesn't know what it's about, "Orphan" is about a mother who's looking to adopt after a miscarriage and adopts an orphan, who is obviously a psycho. I like how the film was about 2 hours long. It has more of a backbone story with it, more than a lot of other horror films. There's something about the movie that's really creepy, and the ending will most likely keep you on the edge of your seat. The film wasn't entirely scary to me, as I wasn't really scared from it (although some scenes were shocking, creepy, and unexpected). There is a great amount of border-line neurotic melodrama that actually works for this film. This film also isn't all about the killing, it's more psychological, actually.All the scenes in the film were put together wonderfully, as it resembles the "creepy kid" type of horror movies really well, but it doesn't fall into much cliche, either. I bet if this film were in Spanish, American critics would have liked it better, but who cares about what they say, because this is a uniquely crafted and brilliant thrill ride of a horror movie.
summary: "Orphan" is a horror film you shouldn't miss

Her adopted mother starts to suspect a terrible secret lies behind her. Eventually, things will escalate to murder. Well filmed (though there are too many false suspense moments) and especially well scripted, this movie has a final twist that I will not discuss here as not to spoil it to future viewers, but let me say that it is very nifty, it makes a lot of sense of what we just see before and puts this movie well above other run of the mill demon child stories. 12 year old's Isabelle Fuhmann performance as Esther is just mind blowing. Vera Farmiga, as the troubled mother seeing with impotence how this girl from hell is breaking her family is also fine.

reviewText: The poster and trailers make Orphan look like a horror movie, but it's not. I won't spoil the surprise except to say it's a suspense/thriller. As such it's a pretty good way to spend movie night if you don't expect too much or think too hard. Twist endings are de rigueur for the horror/suspense genre, with some directors thinking the more ludicrous and outlandish, the better. Thankfully, Orphan doesn't insult the audience's intelligence with a cheap surprise ending just for the sake of twist endings (seeThe Village). All the characters in here act naturally and do things that are logical for who they are, unlike some movies where the director shows characters doing things to intentionally mislead the audience or other red herrings, even when they are alone, like inWild Things. The revelation at the end is credible and logical, though it shouldn't be a big shock unless you've totally switched off your brain before pushing the play button. The ending does not require a huge suspension of disbelief, and while you may not have guessed it, it won't leave you thinking you've been conned. I commend director Jaume Collet-Serra for taking us on a little side road along this well-traveled path (Child's Play,The Omen [Blu-ray],The Bad Seed).The film is mostly devoid of the usual cheap tricks that characterize horror/thriller films, like sudden loud music when a door opens, things popping out, or the slow, closely-framed behind the shoulder shot that suddenly cuts to a scary person behind the victim or a face in the mirror (accompanied by loud music). "There's something wrong with Esther", as the tagline says, and I didn't find any spots where I jumped in my seat. The Orphan does not produce an intense feeling of tension or fear, and instead, settles for a slow, hovering mood of creepiness before leading to the explosive final confrontation.Of note are Isabelle Fuhrman (Esther), 12, and Aryana Engineer, 8, who plays Max the hearing impaired and mute little sister (she is hearing impaired in real life). Fuhrman's fake Russian accent is distracting at times, but her acting abilities are apparent. Sure, her orphan character is a cliche, but Furhman's performance is perfectly creepy and cold. While not ground-breaking, the Orphan is a worthwhile flick to enjoy on a dark evening.
summary: Not perfect, but very enjoyable if you go along for the ride

reviewText: A family of four is torn apart after adopting a seemingly sweet and intelligent Russian girl. Her mysterious past catches up with them as a series of accidents befall the family members and anyone else that crosses Esther's path. ORPHAN was a big hit upon its release in 2009, despite its many setbacks that keep it from becoming a classic in the killer kids genre. The character of Esther is written and played far too menacingly for her to remain unnoticed. There is no ambiguity in her actions, as she is clearly portrayed as being evil from the very start. As a result, much of the film relies on the shock of her actions rather than the build up or suspense leading up to them. It does, however, manage to maintain the mystery behind her shady background long enough to give the audience one final surprise! Esther's adopted parents are easily the most frustrating parents in recent Horror. Her crackpot mother is irritating and irresponsible, while her idiot father stands completely oblivious to her evil ways in light of the horrible tragedies that are affecting his family. They gain no sympathy or support as a result. If films were graded solely on their twist endings, ORPHAN would rate at the top of its class, but the carelessness of the writing cannot be overcome by the clean cinematography or Isabelle Fuhrman's creepy performance as Esther.-Carl ManesI Like Horror Movies

reviewText: "There's something wrong with Esther," say the ads for "Orphan," and indeed, there is. I could just end the review with that, as it does pretty much tell you everything you need to know about the main character, an adopted girl who promises heaven and delivers hell. But then I'd miss out on the opportunity to tell you about all the other great things it has to offer. This is a truly great horror movie, ambitious enough to be frightening and absorbing, confident enough to toy with the conventions we know all too well, mature enough to rely on the talents of actors instead of the sex appeal of teenagers. Its greatest achievement is transcending the cliché that is the precocious yet evil child, and while I'd like to elaborate on that, I'm afraid the nature of the plot doesn't allow for such details. Regardless, what happens is most likely not what you think will happen, which is to say that you'll actually be surprised.Esther is played by Isabelle Furhman, a twelve-year-old playing a nine-year-old, although age doesn't count much here. She speaks with a flawless Russian accent and masterfully runs the emotional gamut between sweet and sadistic. Esther is a consummate manipulator, able to advertise herself as the nicest girl you'd ever want to raise as your own before switching gears and making those who stand in her way suffer. We first see her sitting all alone in the classroom of an orphanage, painting a colorful and happy picture that tells a story. Her dress is nice, if a little old fashioned, and the ribbons she has tied around her neck and wrists make her look like a princess. When she smiles, it's not the toothy perfection of a mouthwash commercial but a real girl's smile--so cute and innocent and loveable. Her words are eloquent, and she definitely possesses a wisdom beyond her years. Maybe the trauma of losing her parents back in Russia has forced her to grow up a little too fast.For these very reasons, she immediately attracts the attention of a couple looking to adopt after a miscarriage claims the life of their third baby. Here enters Kate and John Coleman (Vera Farmiga and Peter Sarsgaard), who both carry a lot of baggage. Kate, once a successful piano teacher, is a recovering alcoholic who feels nothing but guilt. John, an architect, is a nice enough guy but takes everything at face value, a character flaw that ultimately proves disastrous.Esther is adopted. Now things start to get tense. At school, she's made fun of for her clothing and her old, dilapidated Bible, and she screams bloody murder when someone goes to touch the ribbon on her neck. At home, she's hated by the Coleman's son, Daniel (Jimmy Bennett), who rightfully feels ignored by his parents. She soon forms an unhealthy bond with the Coleman's deaf young daughter, Max (Aryana Engineer), who eventually sees things that no little girl should ever have to see. As for the relationship between Esther and Kate, it gets progressively worse while the relationship with John gets progressively better. But Kate knows that there's something wrong with Esther, and it has nothing to do with the little things like dropping an F-bomb; it has to do with serious things, like Esther being present when her mean schoolmate falls from the top of a playground set and breaks her ankle.One of the nuns from the orphanage, Sister Abigail (CCH Pounder), seems to think Kate is on to something: "Trouble has a way of finding her," she says of Esther, believing that a mistake might have been made in the adoption process. But what if they were nothing more than accidents? What if Kate is wrong? Is it possible that she's venting her resentments on a girl who has been through a lot? Is it possible that she should be back in rehab? Kate's therapist, Dr. Browning (Margo Martindale), seems to think so, and apparently, so does John. But what about their children? Let's just say they know more than care to admit. Think of it in terms of one of Esther's paintings; when you look it in a different light, you'll find that a completely different story is being told."Can you keep a secret?" the ads ask us ominously, if not altogether unexpectedly. Indeed, you should keep the film's big revelation to yourself, even if you found it unconvincing. Suspension of disbelief is required of you, yes, but fortunately, this is one of the few recent horror films that earns it. Why? Because the story doesn't resort to cheap gimmicks--it's a thriller that actually thrills. There are moments that seem to be leading up to a tired horror cliché, only to throw us off guard with ... nothing. When a door or a medicine cabinet is opened, blocking the camera's view, what do you expect to see in the shot when the door closes? In this movie, you're never sure whether or not someone will suddenly appear out of nowhere. If it does happen, chances are it's for reasons other than a quick scare.The more lasting scares involve Esther, who at one point or another makes use of a hammer, a gun, a vice, a knife, a pillow, a retractable blade, and a match with a bottle of lighter fluid. Even a car rolling backwards down a hill in neutral finds its way into the story. As has been repeatedly said, there's something wrong with Esther, a girl who makes little Rhoda from "The Bad Seed" seem like an amateur. "Orphan" is a first class shocker that begins with a nervous whisper before building to a cry and ending with a scream. Director Jaume Collet-Serra and writers Alex Mace and David Leslie Johnson actually made an effort; yes, their film is scary, and yes, their film is disturbing, but more to the point, their film is engaging.

reviewText: I was honestly floored when I saw critics call this film "unrealistic" due to the fact that everyone seems to trust Esther (the psychopath homicidal girl) over her truth-telling but seemingly paranoid mother and a typical "It's always the parents' fault, not the child's" incompetent but far-from-uncommon therapist. Most horror films suffer from intense unbelievability, but this is definitely not one of them. It's only because *we* see the truth do we wonder how everyone can believe Esther over her mother. What no one seems to grasp is that they *WANT* to believe what they say, and the motivations every character has are definitely not unreasonable--if they took the mother's word, they'd be jumping into blaming the child for such horrific things, and it would almost invariably end in a downward spiral that would tear an already-salvaged family apart.I was impressed with the realism of every character. They even use the pathology "antisocial personality disorder" properly, and a totally believable family therapist who, like many other incompetent therapists, immediately blames the parents, not the children, for their problems. A therapist blaming the mother for her child's behavior is par for the course for many of these therapists, despite any and all evidence that the child is simply unruly, even with events that happen because of Esther.The two biological family members, Max and Daniel, have been criticized for being unrealistic, for not talking after seeing Esther do such horrific things. This is a mistake by critics. These are young children we're talking about who are, naturally, terrified of Esther, who threatens them with such intimidation that they don't care about anything except keeping her away from them, which means keeping quiet under any and all circumstances. Such young children can't understand that type of situation and the seriousness of it, and I really don't think it's such a stretch to say they would do the simplest thing and avoid Esther entirely so they don't get hurt, rather than tell someone and risk Esther doing the terrifying things she says she'll do if they talk. If she said the same things to adults, their thinking would be more adult-like, but they're very small children not even in puberty.Esther is also not an unbelievable character, and everyone's unwillingness to blame her despite that she *probably* had something to do with all of the happenings around her is perfectly natural. And the reason for that is because there's really no *actual* evidence that she was involved, and it would be unfair to blame an otherwise well-behaved child, and an orphan with a troubled past, at that. No one would be comfortable going against the quick consensus that the mother is just transferring her own guilt onto Esther. Not even her husband would be able to get past that in the real world. In terms of credibility, Esther simply wins by a landside. The mother is a recovering alcoholic and has periods of mental instability. Esther is a well-behaved, intelligent, and creative orphan who simply knows how to manipulate others behind their backs. She knows that they'll blame the mother the more she complains about Esther for things she can't find real evidence for. Esther is smart. The mother has no chance of winning the credibility war with no real evidence against Esther.Anyway, people who are complaining about how there's no way Esther could do the things she does and also that other kids would cover for her out of fear are mistaken. None of that is unrealistic given the context. The mother already starts off as someone to be watched for instability, and already lacks credibility before they even take Esther in. When her mother insists Esther is responsible for the bizarre happenings going on, we're talking about a not-so-perfect unstable mother against a well-behaved, creative child who knows exactly how to cover her own tracks, and in fact likes that her mother is so enraged about it, which only helps her own stability come off as credible.This is really an excellent thriller, one of my favorites. Esther is a true psychopath to the letter, and the way the film treats the nature of psychopathy is exceptional. It's a believable story, and the two hours rocket by while we watch Esther's psychopathy manifest more and more, and the suspense never lets up. Extremely highly recommended for horror and thriller fans.

reviewText: ORPHANSTARRING: Vera Farmiga, Peter Sarsgaard, Isabelle Fuhrman, Jimmy Bennett, Aryana Engineer and CCH PounderWRITTEN BY: David Johnson and Alex MaceDIRECTED BY: Jaume Collette-SerraRated: RGenre: Horror / ThrillerRelease Date: 24 July 2009I'd be lying if I said that Orphan didn't have all the little moments you have seen a thousand times in horror flicks and thrillers. You know the ones I mean; the loud noises, the fast camera jerks and the annoying false-alarm-scares. It has them all. So why did I give it such a high rating you might ask?Because although it has all of those little tidbits that feel like fillers and has a premise that's been recycled countless times, it has much more than any of the films you are thinking of. It makes movies like The Omen and Rosemary's Baby look like Disney films in comparison. Orphan is beyond disturbing.We feel like a silent guest in the home of Kate (Vera Farmiga) and John (Peter Sarsgaard) Coleman. We feel their love for one another and the love for their children, Max and Daniel but we also sense dark secrets and an essence of mistrust as well. The family is holding it together but there have been some issues, for sure.Kate is a recovering alcoholic and has miss-carried their third child in a very late stage of pregnancy. She had a name picked out and everything. She even dedicated a patch of rare flowers that she grows indoors to the unborn child.This is obviously why things are a bit off with the family, so she and John agree to look into adopting. They've done a pretty decent job raising the two kids they already have, so it's no wonder they are fond of nine-year-old Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman) when they meet her at an orphanage. It's almost hard to believe she can be just nine. She is a very talented artist, plays the piano effortlessly and insists on dressing elegantly all the time. Despite all of this, she is without a doubt creepy.As you may have guessed, at first everything is great. She gets along with the other kids, the parents love and adore her and all is well. Then things start happening. There is a close call here and a questioning concern there and then things get nasty.What sets Orphan apart from similar films of its genre, is that things don't just get bad, they get really, really bad. This kid is one disturbed little individual.Perhaps what made kids scary in movies in the past, was that they were just kids doing bad things. What makes Esther so terrifying is that she acts like an adult when she does them. She's too mature and smart for her own good and that's more horrifying.At times it's almost like she is more aware of things than the parents. I think another factor that works is the way she dresses. They could have very easily tried to make her look eerie with dark clothes and Goth makeup and have her not say anything. Instead they chose to dress her up like a little church girl, complete with ribbons in her hair and dress shoes and they gave her a huge vocabulary and a grown up sense to know things that no child should know.Another element it has that most horror films lack, is good acting. Every character is portrayed so well, it's insane.Vera Farmiga makes us feel her pain in every scene. She is an extraordinary actress and is severely underrated. It was nice to finally see her in a lead role.Peter Sarsgaard may very well be one of the best actors out there. I have seen several of his films and he has so much diversity between his characters. Here he plays denial that anything is wrong with Esther to a T and his chemistry with Farmiga is always believable.Even the other two child actors who play Max, (Aryana Engineer) and Daniel (Jimmy Bennett) did amazing jobs. They both are so convincing that they're horribly scared, you can't help but wonder if they will need therapy after making this movie.The director, (Jaume Collette-Serra) clearly has a knack for horror films, a previous film being 2005's House of Wax, which was also done very well. He keeps you on the edge of your seat and rips amazing performances out of all the actors.The third act of the film was by far the most interesting. All bets are off for predicting anything that will happen. I was shocked repeatedly and amazed by the ending. This was easily the most original ending I have seen in any film since The Sixth Sense.It's good to see that there can still be some decent horror films made. And it's reassuring as an avid horror fan, to know that good solid actors like Farmiga and Sarsgaard are interested in the material and that talented directors like Collette- Serra are behind the reins. Even mainstream icons like Michael Bay, Peter Jackson, Sam Raimi, and Martin Scorsese have been conjuring up new horror films.It will probably take several years, if ever, for anyone to see Isabelle Fuhrman as not creepy. She does for scary little kids what Anthony Hopkins did for deranged serial killers. I wonder how this role has affected her because she conveys such evil in her performance, that you are impressed and repulsed simultaneously. And I also wonder if her parents will have any trouble finding a babysitter after this.

reviewText: It's been a while since we've had a movie where a child played the bad guy, or in this case, the bad girl. This movie really exceeded my expectations as I was expecting another predictable and corny horror flick. "Orphan" is billed as a horror movie, but in actuality it is a psychological thriller. Any way you slice it (no pun intended), this turned out to be a very good movie.The first thing that comes to mind while watching this movie is "The Good Son" (1993), but "Orphan" has a better plot, more twists & turns, a more deranged child, and more surprises than you'd expect. Actually, Esther (the Orphan) is so evil and mentally disturbed that she makes "The Good Son" seem like a choir boy. Like other movies with this theme, the mother becomes suspicious early-on that something isn't quite right about the child, while the father plays the head-in-the-sand do-do who just doesn't get it until it's too late.This flick is not about the supernatural or demons and such; it's just about one conniving, creepy, crazy a** kid who was adopted from an orphanage and who terrorized the hell out of a somewhat ordinary family struggling to overcome some tragic life events. This is one of those movies that you can't say too much about without giving away the entire plot, but I can say that "Orphan" is quite entertaining and is definitely worth seeing. It has great acting, a good plot, a great lead character, a little humor, numerous twists & turns, good suspense and a surprise ending. In fact, I'm anticipating a possible "Orphan II".

reviewText: this is really vera farmiga's film. she carries it every step of the way with her expressive and believable acting. by comparison her husband, therapist and the orphanage counselor occupy less nuanced roles. that clears the decks for a full exploration of the tension between this loving and damaged mother and her new adopted daughter. her *strange* adopted daughter.what's up with that child? you can't put your finger on it. yes, you soon get the evidence that the family is in serious trouble. the script brings in the usual thriller subplots that require the child's schoolyard tormenter to get what she doesn't deserve, or the mother to dig into the child's obscure past, or the bland and clueless father to get his shocking realization. but none of this is to the question: what is the child's motivation, why does she do what she does?well, there are clues along the way that don't quite fit in but that, at the end, make perfect sense. such as: why is this child afraid to go to the dentist? and why can she play the piano like a virtuoso?there are some witty turns here and there -- this is perhaps the first film to cast a playground as a haunted house -- but there are some resonant touches of psychology as well -- the tensions in an adulterous marriage, the mother's grief and guilt, the sibling rivalries, the secrets. but what's up with that child? the final disclosure makes her plausible in an unexpected way, and the final battle between mother and daughter is kept roaring with one twist after another. a distinctive and engrossing thriller.

reviewText: Evil kid movies are inherently creepy. Kids are supposed to be victims in movies not the other way around, so when you do see it it makes your skin crawl. This is a good entry into the genre.A couple adopts a girl from an orphanage. Things seem to be OK in the beginning but deteriorate at a rapid pace.The strength here is in the way the story unfolds. We meet a seemingly happy, loving couple, but as things progress we see their dark sides and weaknesses. The viewer gets glimpses of infidelity, alcoholism, mental instability, et al. Same with their adopted girl. Certain flags pop up right away, but they get larger and larger with each passing scene.There are weaknesses as well. I like Peter Skarsgaard, but he's weak here and I can't say it's in the script. He just isn't all there. Vera Farmiga, on the other hand, does a great job. Her realization of what is happening and the subsequent trying to impart it to those around her is an uphill battle, particularly given her less than stable past. But she really sinks her teeth into it and displays the whole "deep love of a mother" thing with resounding aplomb.The other major weakness is the climax/ending. The storyline is laid out very well until then. And outside of the really creepy transformation of the orphan, it's like the writer(s) got stupid all of the sudden and put this unbelievably heavy handed machine into motion. I won't spoil things here but this part of the movie needed to be much smarter and way more clever. It's bad to the point of nearly negating all the cool stuff that came before. Maybe the producers listened too closely to their test audiences.This is a generally good movie with good work in front of and behind the camera. Ending not withstanding, it's well worth the viewer's time investment.

reviewText: Move over Samara, Wednesday Addams and all you juvenile miscreants.  There's a new pint-size queen of evil and her name is Esther.  Brilliant, charming and oh-so-talented, she harbors a host of dark secrets behind herinnocent, smiling face.  But when you finally learn what they are it'll probably be too late.Anyone who has read my prior movie reviews knows that I love good horrorand suspense films.  Unfortunately, nowadays most offerings in the genre are long on gore and short on story and character development.  That's not so with this time around, though.  Heavy on atmosphere and with very little blood, the movie relies more on suggestion, dark sets and outstanding acting to create its air of malevolence and all pervading evil.The story concerns a tightly knit, loving family that is nonetheless marred by tragic events in its past, including the father's adultery and the mother's tumultuous recovery from alcoholism.  But the most heart wrenching nightmare they have endured is the loss of their third child, who was stillborn.  It weighs especially heavy on the mother, who struggles daily to cope with her depression and crushing sense of loss.Seeking to make some good come of the horrific event, they adopt a highly intelligent, articulate and artistically gifted young girl from eastern Europe.  Her name is Esther, and at first she brings happiness and healing into their lives.  But soon they find out that she is not what she seems, no, not at all.In my opinion the film's strongest asset is the brilliant performance by 12 year old actress Isabelle Fuhrman, who plays the title character.  She portrays Esther as a complex, multi-leveled character who possesses both admirable qualities and pathologically wicked desires.During the movie my feelings for her went from affection, to pity, then to uneasiness and horror as her deepest, most twisted secret was revealed in a climactic moment that had me on the edge of my seat.Set in Connecticut during a bleak winter, the icy scenery is the perfect backdrop for the tension that mounts throughout the movie.  Esther first takes revenge on a girl at school who mocks her for her unusual clothing and quiet, studious demeanor.  Then she turns on those who threaten to reveal her past.  Finally the family that has taken her into their home feels her wrath.  The mother alone suspects the truth, but finds herself outwitted by her psychopathic opponent at every turn.The final 20 minutes or so were filled with twists that kept me befuddled as to how it would all end, and I am very good at figuring out hidden plot elements.  For example, I suffered the misfortune of figuring out the secret to "The Sixth Sense" very early in that film.That was not the case this time.  The producers clearly took great pains to avoid the worn out devices used in one cheesy horror movie after another.  In their place they devised a story line so uniquely insidious that it hit me like a wall of bricks when it was finally revealed.Haunting, disturbing, terrifying and unforgettable - all these words and more describe this outstanding film.  I strongly recommend you shell out the money for the tickets and popcorn and see this one on the big screen.  It's worth every penny.
summary: Esther has REALLY got something wrong with her!

reviewText: *THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS*Yes, this is another "Bad Seed" movie, as I've noticed critics of the movie have complained. But I liked it. I thought it had enough twists to set itself apart. Make sure, however, that you don't miss the originalThe Bad Seedfrom 1956. That one's the best.Parts of the movie were predictable, of course. It's obvious from the beginning that the bad things happening are probably because of Esther, the orphan, even though we don't actually SEE her doing anything at first. After all, doesn't it say "There's something wrong with Esther" right on the cover of the movie?! Then of course, there's the wife who suspects something and the husband who rationalizes away all her fears. And everyone who gets too close to knowing gets hurt. Very typical.What we don't know is WHY Esther is this way. And actually, that never really becomes clear. You would think if Esther could finally just find a family to stick with, maybe she could have somewhat of a normal life. After all, this family cared about her, and if people hadn't been dropping like flies, no one would have investigated. Anyway, we find out that Esther is really a grown woman with dwarfism. It was a plot twist I was not expecting, but it explained everything. And it was sad. Like I said, it didn't really explain why Esther was the way she was. She couldn't change her past, but no one was looking for her. She could have moved on.The best part about the movie was the acting. I was beyond impressed with Isabelle Fuhrman as Esther. When a 12-year-old can pull off a part like that... well, that's just natural talent. She sure has not had much time for training. Too many young actors and actresses these days seem to get parts just because they're in the right place at the right time, or they're related to someone. And then their talent involves taking their clothes off. (We will hope she doesn't go that way.)The only bummer was the end. While it was well-acted, I was thrown off by her being such an old hag! She was seriously ugly. They cannot expect us to believe she turned that face into a sweet 9-year-old girl with a little bit of make-up every morning. They probably needed 3 hours of make-up just to age Isabelle in the opposite direction! Geez, most women can barely make themselves look 5 years younger with makeup. I think a making-of featurette would have been nice, but there were no special features at all. Maybe they realized they overdid the makeup and didn't want to draw attention to it?

reviewText: Simply put, Isabelle Fuhrman dominates the screen as Esther, a cute 9-year-old Russian girl adopted by a loving family that wishes to fill the void of a recent pregnancy that resulted in a stillborn.  Adopted by John and Kate (Peter Sarsgaard and Vera Farmiga, respectively), Esther soon ratchets up the mystery and tension in this suspense thriller.  At odds are the family's two children; innocent Max (Aryana Engineer), who forms a quick bond with Esther, and surly Daniel (Jimmy Bennett), who irritated me and Esther from the very moment the camera began rolling.Esther appears to be a great addition to the family, what with her old-fashioned appearance, ribbons and dress like a Little Bo Peep story, but soon enough Kate becomes more curious and suspicious of the talented little girl's background.  Meanwhile, John plays the role of doormat, making bad decisions and letting his somewhat abrasive wife dominate screen time.  Rather than pimping their children out for reality show riches, this John and Kate bicker weakly about their new daughter and the effect she is having on their family.What unfolds is an exercise in tension and patience.  While Kate slowly unravels the mystery, Esther shows wisdom by manipulating everyone towards her side.  Those against her?  Not so lucky.The most compelling part of Orphan, and what saved the film's slow pace, was the performance of Fuhrman.  At 11-years old she possesses the acting chops to pull off a flawless Russian accent while displaying emotional range of which most adults are incapable.  With a flick of the emotional switch, she changes from innocent to sadistic, friendly to evil.  A very convincing performance.For once it seems Hollywood was capable of making a movie that didn't rely on the one-second shock scares.  Dark to light.  Quiet to loud.  This pleased me quite a bit while watching this movie.  Director Jaume Collet-Serra and screenplay writer David Johnson have created an ambitious film that doesn't fit into the mold of most current horror or suspense thrillers; what they have made is almost old-fashioned.  There is very little in the way of ambiguity; what's evil is evil, what's good is good.  It's up to the viewer to follow a path.  Regardless of choice, the ending is quite a surprise.Jason Elin

reviewText: Many people find that describing the movie to give a movie review is the way to go. Usually, I refrain, but on this occasion, I will include the plot. A husband and wife, already with two children of their own (one who is deaf) lose their third child during labor. They resort to adopting an orphan--a 9-year-old, seemingly intelligent and kind-hearted, little Russian girl. Much to their dismay, what seems to be the perfect adoption turns into anything but. The movie moves at a slow but determined pace for the first 45 minutes or so, but then the rockin' starts to rollin' as the story spirals into a cacophony of strangeness accompanied with mountains of vindictive mayhem. Many reviews I have read had a problem with the twist; I thought it to be VERY COOL, and something that could become reality in the realm of possibility, which makes it all the more founded, thus being all the more horrific. Just before the twist; however, something happened that made me think, "Okay, here we go...right back into the silly Hollywood horror film crap that has been bombarding us throughout the beginning of the new century." But when the twist hits and everything finally makes sense, I was thankfully pulled from that train of thought and taken back into a bizarre and wonderful story. Dark Castle Entertainment has done a LOT of movies that I simply love (Gothika, Ghost Ship, and Thirteen Ghosts.) This one will have to go into that group of five-star movies. Don't miss it!FIVE STARS ***** for everything being done the way it should be done!

reviewText: For those of you that like thrillers like "Single White Female," "Fatal Attraction," or "Audition," this is another shocker in the same vein. Although "Orphan" has some genuine thrills and scares, it made me feel a little unclean at times.When "Orphan" begins, we meet the Colemans: Kate (Vera Farmiga) and John (Peter Saargard), and their children Daniel (Jimmy Bennett) and Max (Arayana Engineer). After the stillborn death of their third child, Kate and John decide to adopt one. At the orphanage, they become enchanted with a little girl named Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman). At first, she appears the child from heaven: she immediately bonds with Max, and learning sign language to communicate with her (Max is deaf). But strange things start happening around Esther...This is what "The Good Son" could have been, had it been better written and acted. Yet, even though it rectifies the main fault I had with that movie (nothing the psychotic Macauley Culkin character did was really evil enough), that comes at a price. Children (specifically Esther) act violently in this film, and at times it crosses the line between suspense-building and unsettling. While I'll agree that having a child commit this crimes gives the film an extra punch, some (though not all) of the scenes left me feeling dirty and violated.Still, all in all, this is an impressive thriller. The most important part of a thriller is a good villain, and Esther is truly frightening. At age 12, Isabelle Fuhrman has quite the capability to scare the living hell out of anyone. She's right up there with Jennifer Jason Leigh and Eihi Shiina, or more applicably, Jacob Kogan from "Joshua," which coincidentally also starred Vera Farmiga. The other cast members acquit themselves well too. Vera Farmiga is in top-form as Kate, though she's been here before (in fact, she plays almost the exact same character as she did in "Joshua"). Peter Saarsgard, a talented actor from the independent film circuit, plays a type, but he does solid work. However, the script calls for him to be dumber than is realistically plausible, and Saarsgard can't make us believe that his character is really that oblivious. The child actors are great as well. Jimmy Bennett is solid in an unspectacular part of Daniel.But Arayana Engineer is perfect as Max. She's adorable, and although very young, Engineer draws our sympathy like a magnet. I never stop rooting for her actually.Apart from the amorality of some of the scenes, not everything that director Jaume Collet-Serra does works. He attempts to create scares where they have no place, and the failures of these elicited laughs from the audience. Speaking of laughs, there is a bit of humor in the film, and that works. However, one of the scenes is so over-the-top that it's unintentionally hilarious.I recommend it, if you've got a thick skin for this sort of thing.

reviewText: This nifty old-school thriller pulled extremely mixed reviews when it landed in theaters last summer.  Because my two most trusted critics liked it (Ebert and Owen Gleiberman from EW), I went to see it and enjoyed it immensely.Now that the film is on DVD (and now that I know the twist), I can appreciate the movie again from a fresh perspective, and I still think it's a first-class piece of suspense, as well as one of the best "evil child" movies I've ever seen.  (It also beats "Joshua" hands-down, despite what the critic Amazon cites above says.)Really, the script is tight, the direction is fine, and most of all, the performances are excellent.  Except for the fact that thrillers rarely get their due at Oscar time, Farmiga and Fuhrman both give Oscar-worthy performances, and CCH Pounder makes a memorable impression as well.But I must note two major caveats: the pace is slow and deliberate; folks with ADD will never make it all the way through the film, or they'll be fiddling with their Blackberries halfway through the first reel.  Those who like a well-crafted piece of suspense will settle in and enjoy the ride, however.The second caveat: under NO circumstance should children under 10 see this film!!!  In fact, I have to assume that the producers had counselors on the movie set to explain "this is just a story" to the child actors; little Esther really terrorizes her adopted siblings, as well as one unfortunate classmate!The only reason I have deducted one star is the lack of special features on the DVD.  There are some brief extra scenes plus an alternate ending (which is creepy but not as exciting as the regular ending), but that's it.  NO "making of" featurette, NO commentary.  In particular, I would have liked to have heard what Fuhrman and the other kids thought of the movie, whether they had nightmares, etc.So Warner Brothers, like the critics, did this chilling thriller a significant disservice.  Judging from the majority of favorable reviews here at Amazon, I have to believe that this film's reputation will improve over the years, and perhaps after a decade or two, WB will release a "Special Edition" with the extra features such a fine effort deserves.Two thumbs up!
summary: There's Something Wrong with the Critics

reviewText: "Orphan" is without a doubt one of the most silly and over-the-top suspense movies that I have seen in ages. It has everything. A couple (Peter Sarsgaard & Vera Farmiga) who are getting over a recent tragedy, a busy-body nun (CCH Pounder) who simply won't keep her nose out of other people's affairs, a deaf child (Aryana Engineer) who can probably communicate better than most people and then there's Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman). There are some scenes where you may even route for Esther because at first she comes off as the ultimate victim and who doesn't like a victim? Esther gets her revenge, but good. I thought it was hysterical how Kate got all up in arms when Esther nonchalantly said the F-curse. Umm, lady you were busy doing it in the middle of your kitchen, yet you get all disturbed because your newly adopted child who walks in on you says a naughty word. But, lemme just say if Esther  were my adopted child I would send her to the Leona Helmsley school for bad girls and she'd learn really quickly how to behave. Esther is actually hiding a dark and very shocking secret which will amaze you and cause you to gasp in horror (trust me, it's a biggie). But this movie is so much more than a suspense or a thriller. It's the ultimate game of cat and mouse. The question is, who is the cat and who is the mouse? Remember, don't repeat the surprise shock ending...

reviewText: In this age of computer graphics and special effects came this little gem, which needed not rely on either. As well, it is only right that I mention that for a horror thriller, the performances were fantastic. The plot keeps the audience interested throughout the film.There are similarities between this and a few other films. The Good Son starring Macaulay Culkin at first came to mind.From the atmosphere all the way through to the plot...this movie truly delivers!I have viewed this film twice at the theatre and it was just as good the second time around as it was for the first.The young actors in this film are as good as the adults and it's the acting that brings this film out of pure mediocrity!The Orphan is a welcome edition to the horror/thriller genre and is not a film that you are likely to forget once you see it!Compared to many of the horrible horror films that make it to theatrical release...this film was worthy of being released theatrically!The film's character is more sadistic than 'The Good Son' and more evil than 'The Bad Seed.'This is not Damien from The Omen series...but Esther can hold her own in the world of evil movie children.Sure, there have been many, from The Children of the Damned all the way through to The Children of the Corn.Whatever the case may be...there's something very special about Esther!I can't recommend this movie enough to fans of the genre!The family's home is beautiful, as well as the Canadian scenery used to add another special quality to this film which would otherwise be lacking!I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and I felt that most everything that was included in the film was needed to further the plot along.There were no elements of it that weren't necessary.Whether it was meant to establish the relationship between the husband and the wife...and their issues, or the parents' relationship with their children...it was all NECESSARY!In the end, all the elements come together and we are presented with a film that amazes us, surprises us and maybe even frightens us a bit!There are funny moments throughout that provide us with a sense of dark humor, but when it comes down to it, this is not a funny film, but a deeply disturbing movie!It kept me on the edge of my seat throughout it's 2 hour running time. In fact, I hated to see it end.I will revisit this little treasure again, as well as adding it to my personal movie collection!There are a few surprises thrown into this film that might surprise you.It will keep you on edge and you WILL genuinely care about the characters in the movie.Having seen numerous horror thrillers, I believe that this added something special to the genre that we don't see very much: a talented cast of actors giving it all they've got in order to make a believable movie for the audience to enjoy!Great acting in a horror thriller is few and far between!This film is definitely NOT for children and although this is not a gory picture...it is still very disturbing!I am particularly fond of movies that can touch us emotionally, and yet, disturb us as well!You feel the love of the parents for their children and vice versa.As well, the relationship between the parents is very well written and it adds a dynamic to the new developing relationship between Esther and her new dad!At the same time that mom and dad are drifting apart...it is helping to bring the developing father/daughter relationship closer together!Being that Esther is so manipulative...she had dad playing right into her hands...or so she thinks. At the same time...she makes it look as if mom's prior alcohol problem is beginning to resurface again!The young actors in this film are very convincing and as they are threatened, scared and concerned for their lives...we see it in their faces and they portray their roles with much accuracy!The role of Esther was brilliantly portrayed by Isabelle Fuhrman.It is probably the best single performance of a child actress in the history of this genre!However, I truly hope that this role does not come back to haunt her...as her acting is very versatile...so Hollywood should take notice of this up and coming STAR!All in all, you will be impressed by the acting skills of the entire family in this movie!They all gave 110% to their roles!The Orphan is a disturbing film guaranteed to keep you entertained the entire time you sit in front of the screen.The movie is guaranteed to throw a surprise at you before it's over and I doubt very much that you figure out what it is!The characters are very well developed and the character of Esther was brilliantly portrayed. There is a sense of innocence present...but beneath the facade lies a very dangerous, manipulative and sadistic personality!Isabelle shows great ability in her portrayal of this complex character!The movie offers much sentiment early on and this helps us later to care for the film's characters more than we would if they hadn't been so well developed!It seems that this little girl is intent on tearing her new family apart.She does her best to fit in...but it's difficult for a disturbed child like Esther to make friends...much less to keep them.Mom and brother suspect that things are not as they seem and over the course of the movie, we realize this as well.The intriguing thing is that the audience cannot wait to see what will happen next...and that's how I knew that I was witnessing a great film!I was truly surprised as the movie went along with many of the twists thrown into the mix.This is a five star thriller with fantastic actors and a fantastic script.As the movie's tagline says, "There's Something Wrong With Esther."As well, there is something wrong with you if you don't see this movie!Enjoy! Highly Recommended!

reviewText: (Possible Spoilers)After the death of a young child, a couple has been debating for a while whether to adopt another child to be a part of their family, they visit an orphanage and the wife Kate (Vera Farminga, "The Departed") sees a young girl named Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman, "Hounddog"). This does sound like a pretty basic story of a disturbed orphaned kid, but the story by Alex Mace, David Leslie Johnson's screenplay and Jaume Collet-Serra's directing do lend some very good dark tones to this and they keep the chills and terror coming, even if the viewer can figure out whats gonna happen long before it does."Orphan" is actually a very well done movie, it has a feeling of dread everytime Esther is on screen as you're just waiting for something to happen, there's also the underlying storyline of troubles between Kate and John from things that happened in their recent past. The daughter's deafness does come into play during key parts of the movie and while most everyone does well in their roles Isabelle really breaks out as Esther as its easily one of the most layered characters from the thriller/horror genre in recent memory.Its better to be watched and enjoyed, course if you've read other reviews you know the twist already which I did catch before it was totally revealed however the revelation in the movie was well done and seeing the terror on Vera's face was pretty tense and cool to see. **** out of 4 stars.

reviewText: Vera Farmiga, Peter Sarsgaard, and CCH Pounder give excellent performances, but it's the kiddies who steal the show in "Orphan."Farmiga and Sarsgaard star as Kate and John Coleman, a successful and loving (or so it seems at first) couple with two children and the desire to adopt another when Kate's third child is stillborn.  They believe that they've found the perfect child in Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman), a nine-year-old Russian orphan who is sugary sweet, highly intelligent, and very artistic.Once Esther arrives at the Coleman home, she is immediately met with resistance by the Coleman's son, Daniel (Jimmy Bennett), and takes their deaf daughter, Max (Aryana Engineer) under her protective wing.  She is also teased at school for her dresses and the Bible she carries with her.Slowly the viewer sees sweet Esther turn into a very dark and sinister little girl.  Not only does she seek out revenge on those who pick at her, but she begins to manipulate Max and force her to help out with her dirty work.Esther also opens old wounds from Kate and John's past and drives a wedge between them.  Kate becomes suspicious of Esther and seeks out more information on her newly adopted daughter.  The head mistress of the orphanage, Sister Abigail (CCH Pounder), tries to help Kate and becomes a target for Esther as well.As Esther's dark past is revealed, her actions become more wicked and, in some cases, fatal.  It is at this point that the film begins to rely on well-worn cliches that have been trod out in a number of other films about evil children, particularly "The Good Son" and "The Omen."Naturally there is a twist thrown in near the film's climax in order to give a motive to Esther's madness, and while it is rather sickening, it's not that big of a surprise.Overall, the film isn't that bad.  However, clocking in at a very slow moving 120-plus minutes makes for a somewhat boring experience.  I'm assuming that director Jaume Collet-Serra was trying to build suspense by drawing out the film, but it makes for a lackluster thriller in the end.  Even the climactic battle near the end of the film is drawn out and rather unbelievable.  It's almost as if the film is attempting to be a psychological thriller and a slasher flick at the same time.Again, the film really isn't that bad, just too long and a bit boring at times.  The children all shine in their roles, particularly little Aryana Engineer, whom I believe does an excellent job as Max.  Her performance is overshadowed somewhat by Fuhrman's turn as Esther, but she still shines on her own.So is this film worthy of purchase?  If you enjoy psychological thrillers involving young children then, yes, I say go out and buy it.  However, I do recommend to everyone else that you rent this film first.  It's good, but I have no plans to add it to my permanent collection any time soon.
summary: Strong Cast Shines In A Slow-Paced Thriller

reviewText: Orphanwas a movie that I'd heard about and was hesitant to watch. Peter Sarsgaard portrays John, the husband, whom we soon learn has some fidelity issues, thus creating tension between the spouses.Isabelle Fuhrman, as Esther, steals the spotlight as the disturbed adopted daughter.  The other children are very compelling as well, and the movie creates the typical conspiracy of silence between them all, as Esther inspires fear and obedience from them.When Kate begins to suspect something is very wrong with Esther, she can't get her husband to even give credence to her concerns.  He brushes her off as if she's nothing.  I began to despise him early on for his cluelessness and his inability to see what was staring him in the face.In the end, though, everyone is a believer.  And not to give away the surprises, just be sure to watch closely as the layers of this secret begin to unfold.I probably would have given this one 4.5 stars, if I could.  I deducted a star because, despite the compelling nature of this film, it isn't one I'll ever watch again.

reviewText: Sigh. I tell you people that Seers usually bend over backwards in order to please the ladies in our lives. Case in point: Sondra the Seerest (Metamorpho's long time main squeeze) and I were relaxing at my castle, having crackers, cheese and wine, when all of a sudden she said, "You know what Metamorpho? We really should consider adopting a child, not a baby mind you, but one a little older who will add spice and happiness to the castle." To be perfectly frank people, I was taken aback at the suggestion. Certainly I possess enough spice for the whole world, but, despite my hurt small (!) ego, I gave in, always willing to please to avoid total aggravation.So Sondra and Seer sauntered (yes, I am alliterate) down to the local orphange to see if there were any good prospects. Sister Abagail greeted us and in the process I met Esther. She was sitting all alone by herself creating pictures. I was astounded that they were so good for such a young child. And people, I know good art. I did give Picasso lessons after all. Soon Sondra joined us and she was equally as impressed. Esther was remarkable. Creative, well-mannered, attentive, respectful, intelligent and, well, everything every child should be in this mad, a go-go crazy world we all know. At that point I should have been suspicious, however I wasn't (Seers do have lapses you know. One of the very few faults they have I might add). So, it was decided that Sondra and I would go home to think about it and get back to Sister Abigail the next day.Unfortunately (or fortunately) we missed our chance. Sister Abigail called us the next day to tell us that a couple, Kate and John Coleman, decided they wanted her and papers were being drawn up at that very moment. I wasn't too disappointed, but, to play it safe, I told Sondra after sharing 2 bottles of Pinot Grichio. It went better than expected. She only ripped apart 2 of the 50 Rembrandt originals I had hanging in the castle. I caught her on a good day I suppose.Anyway, that brings us to the story of the Colemans. It seems Kate lost a child in pregnancy and needed a child to make her life complete. They already had two children, a small deaf daughter Max, and a scrappy 7 year old boy Daniel. Why anyone would want another child in this economy is a mystery. Then again, the Coleman's had a modern day castle of their own. So John must be doing very well indeed.It must be stated here that Esther was very weird, and certainly not accepted too well by the children. Daniel didn't like her right off the bat. And who ever said children aren't smarter than adults? But, she was weird people. First off, she wore ridiculous dresses to school, the kids taunted her, and plus she had this Russian accent that took getting used to. Oh yes, I almost forgot, Esther had this temper which would make her scream and bash in bathroom walls. Attention getting for sure, but at home she would be a polite young thing.Now, all young couples have their problems. Kate and John were no different, but they had moved beyond the issues of alcoholism and infidelity before Esther arrived. However, we learn that Esther is a master at manipulation and using people's psychological weaknesses to her advantage. So, she became a virtual wedge between the family and exploited their fears and insecurities against each other.Not only that, but strange things were starting to happen. Unfortunate things. Her behaviour started to concern Kate a lot, but John felt that Kate was out on an imagination limb. Kate was in contact with Sister Abagail and when Sister Abigail came for a visit, Mother Superior not only jumped the gun, but jumped the icy curb as well.More and more Kate suspected something wrong with Esther and did reserach over the internet to find out what. Esther, upon psychological investigation,was found to be totally normal and Kate was perceived as a paranoid nut case. So much for experts. However, John perceived the same as the psychologist and saw Esther as a victimized and unfairly treated child, that is, until...Now people, I have given you part of the tasty tidbits here, but not all of them. There is a MAJOR twist here, but I'm not going to tell you. Why? Because I can see the headlines on all the tabloids now. RENOWNED SEER GIVES REVIEW SPOILERS AWAY!!!My fine reputation will suffer and you'll never read my incisive, astute reviews ever again. Reputation is ALL to me (with money a close second). Thus, you will have to see this for yourself. I believe it to be an above-average thriller, and one that, although it takes some while to evolve, will leave you with a feeling as sharp as an icicle - snow pun intended.At first, I thought this movie would be lame. I was most surprised. Although formulaic at times, it was interesting to see the plot unravel. It's definitely worth seeing, especially if you are a suspense-horror-puzzle junkie. With Esther, it's hard to best her, and she proves this time and time again. Somewhat decent story, somewhat decent wondering what's next, but not a classic in the general sense. You know what Esther's about early on. It's waiting for everyone else to catch up to you which is the enjoyment of this movie.After viewing this, Sondra the Seerest has given up the idea of adoption. Good. More time to devote to me! I give it 4 stars, an interesting ride. And, speaking of that, no young ones invited to this. Nothing totally graphic, but enough adult content to keep young eyes away. Besides, do you really want them to grow up like Esther?Another cautionary but slicing review by -- Metamorpho ;)

reviewText: I LOVED it! It's such a skillfully done thriller and one of the best in the evil kid sub-genre period. I loved the set-up. It doesn't take long and you find yourself really caring about this family. There's a wonderful scene early on when Farmiga's character is tucking her daughter into bed.Not only is this entirely successful as a creepy suspense film and even a drama, but it's also downright hilarious. And yes, it's intentional. I loved its sense of humor. The things Esther would say and the way she would say them had me cracking up. She's delightfully evil. Even the murder scenes had me laughing. Just seeing this little girl being so cold and vicious provided a great thrill. And not in a sick way. It was just funny.The performances are great. I found both Vera Farmiga and newcomer Isabelle Fuhrman as Esther to be fantastic.I'd heard so much about the twist before seeing this movie without actually finding out what it was. Despite everyone saying how laughable it was I didn't want to find out until I saw the movie myself. I'm really glad I didn't. I don't think it would have been as enjoyable had I known the whole time. I never saw it coming either. That could be because it's so out there that it's nearly impossible to see it coming. Yet at the same time it wasn't nearly as outrageous as I was fearing judging by the way it was talked about. Thankfully I didn't find it hard to swallow and was able to go along with it. Is it realistic? Not exactly, but it worked fine. It only helps that everything before it was so great. The whole time I was scared that this supposedly horrible twist was going to ruin the movie for me. I'm so glad that wasn't the case.This is a really wicked good time. At a hair over 2 hours it never felt too long. I was having too much fun with this gleefully twisted thrill-ride.The snowy setting was a nice bonus.9/10 (A)

I wish I hadn't known the secret while watching the film, but I still was entertained thanks to some fine acting from both leads and a great performance from the little girl who played the evil Esther. Isabelle Fuhrman was only 11 or so at the time this was filmed, but as far as child actors go, she was the best I've seen in a very long time.I have a couple of gripes. I hated all the times the music built up and the camera zoomed in behind a character only to find there was nothing there in the first place. I know it's a horror movie, but they managed to avoid most other cliches, so why keep throwing this one around? The film is also about 15 minutes too long and I thought the last 1/4 or so dragged a little bit.The weird and unique twist ending, along with the acting, elevated the Orphan from 2 and 1/2 to a 4 star rating from me. The movie reminded me of The Good Son with Macualay Culkin at times, but this one has a much more serious mean streak, most of which involving young kids. This is rated R for a reason. It's way more brutal than I thought it was going to be, especially in the murder scenes commited by the child.Overall, Orphan was worth the five bucks I paid to see it and it definitely should be a rental for any horror or suspense fan in the near future.

reviewText: ISABELLE FUHRMAN, VERA FARMIGA and PETER SARSGAARD are hardly household names to me but they do a superb job of carrying the main suspense ingredients of ORPHAN--as does the atmospheric photography filmed among snowy Canadian landscapes.So do all the other members of the cast--all very convincing in their roles, especially the little deaf girl ARYANA ENGINEER. She's adorable and becomes a pawn in the manipulations of Esther (Fuhrman), the orphan adopted into the household before a background check can reveal the truth about her past.Of course, anyone familiar with the pattern of most horror films of this ilk can spot some of the usual set-ups: a husband who is clueless about seriously suspecting the orphan can be evil, the wife whom nobody believes because she has a drinking problem, the little brother who resents the intrusion of a "different" kind of girl, the well meaning nun whose social worker instincts will lead to her downfall.But many other aspects of the plot come as a surprise and are, to say the least, unexpected and shockingly gruesome.And some threads of the plot can be suspected pretty early on. Still, the final twist at the end is shocking and satisfying, thanks to the performance Fuhrman has so convincingly given. She plays the role with such sweet and sometimes sinister maturity that the final revelation is acceptable.ORPHAN delivers the chills, all staged brilliantly and turns into a horror film that is just as chilly as the ever snowy weather, with frozen ponds and feathery flakes making the indoor sets of a rustic cabin look most inviting.Good direction and superior art decoration, as well as strong performances, makes this an above average thriller.

reviewText: If nothing else the disparate viewer reactions to "The Orphan" make for interesting reading on these comment pages. My advice for potential viewers is to disregard the most extreme love-hate stuff; the film is neither as good nor as bad as a lot of people are saying.It is basically a slightly more bent and graphic version of Julia Stiles' 1998 film "Wicked". Both films revolve around ruthless jockeying for household supremacy, both have an erotic subtext that people seem to be afraid to discuss, and both push the envelope of the "Bad Seed" (1956) genre-reflecting the more extreme attitudes of current fans of the psychological horror genre."Orphan" had a much bigger budget than the earlier films which it quite skillfully utilized in useful areas like production design and cinematography. It is very creative in these areas and Esther (the latest "demon seed"- nicely overplayed by Isabelle Fuhrman) gets a nice dimensionality from the regular showcasing of her art. The painting of the burning orphanage is especially well done and extremely effective; being as creepy as any visual image I have ever seen.I would certainly recommend the film to fans of "Wicked" (and vice versa) and to even causal fans of the horror genre. I think it is too extreme for crossover fans, who would be wise to avoid the film or at least to be prepared to bail at some point because it gets increasingly twisted as it progresses. Unless you are willing to suspend disbelief during a number of plot developments you won't enjoy the viewing. It is a bit like "May" (2002) in this regard, where a lot of viewers enjoy the premise and the set-up but lose interest when the characters get too extreme or too stupid for audience identification.It is a long film (slightly over two hours), which would not be a problem if they had focused more on solving the mystery of Esther's background. Because the film offers viewers minimal cerebral exercises like this, their attention wonders to plot holes and the film begins to get a bit tedious.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

reviewText: Sometimes a film will impress the heck out of me upon a first viewing, but then when I view it again later, it seems to fall flat and I find myself questioning what ever made me like it in the first place.I just rewatched this last night, and I must say that I am so surprised that I ever liked it. Ok, sure, it is well acted, well lit, and well shot, but the story is so preposterous it isn't even funny. Plus, it's edited very poorly, and has an entirely wrong feel for the story that is being told here.Yes, everything good about it, like the good lighting, color schemes, acting, etc etc, all work against the mere simplistic evil child storyline here. And nothing is ever really established as to any of the main character's motives. Yes, it shows that the mother suffered a miscarriage (in the over the top gory opening scene), but that doesn't really explain to me why they would want to adopt a child (who is almost fully grown, mind you), when they already have children. ?I could understand if they were childless, but they already have two children. Plus, if they really wanted another child, why not adopt a newborn baby? ? Anyways, enough about that lapse in logic.And, as for things not ever been really clearly established, well, that also goes for a lot of other scenes in the film. Namely, it is never explained (or fully explored) why the children react the way they do around Esther at school. Plus, the early scenes of little orphan Esther at school had me rooting for her, because it was the other children that came across as the bad seeds, and she was just some innocent outsider. And the whole scene in the playground, I found myself way too distracted wondering why the little girl was so afraid of the orphan girl, that it robbed the film of any form of suspense that it was trying to build in the moment.And the entire "bad seed" plot is kind of well forgotten by the third act, because the tone of the entire picture has shifted so dramatically that it in no way no longer really resembles what it was when it started. Plus, this was such a confused story. I don't mean confusing, but confused, in that it didn't really know what it wanted to be: Was it a thriller, or a horror movie, or was it an erotic thriller that happened to have the "good child is really evil" subplot? (Oh, yes, did I mention that this had way too many over-the-top erotic scenes in it that served absolutely no purpose what-so-ever.)And the entire thing was so way way way over the top it isn't even funny. Ok, well, maybe it is, but not in the way the filmmaker would want it to be. I found myself laughing at the movie so many times I lost count. And I was laughing at them, not with them!Everything is handled in such a heavy handed way, it robs the film of any genuine thrills it should have. There were some scenes that were shot so well, and so well lit, I could watch them over and over, if they were in another film. This may have been better serviced if maybe shot on a lower budget. ? But, as it is, there are way too many well crafted shots wasted on this kind of story.And don't even get me started on the father in this. He is possibly the most irritatingly stupidest character in all horror film history. And especially when he actually broke down and cried in front of the orphan girl, LMAO, how pathetic was that! I wanted to kill him myself!And that leads me to yet another problem I have with this movie (matter of fact, I had this problem the first time I saw it): The extremely over-the-top, gory, gruesome murder of his character. The way it was filmed made me feel like I was inside a snuff film, because it was just too gritty, and again, completely out of tone with the rest of the film.Plus, I almost felt like by that time in the movie, no more characters really needed to be killed off. It was such a blatantly bad decision in plotting in my opinion. And, then, this leads me to the extremely bad, over the top (notice a theme here, lol) ending. Wow, could "Halloween's" ending be ripped off anymore??? You know, the thing that would not die, no matter what you do to it, you know, like, stab it, set it on fire, stab it some more, shoot it, drown it, stab it some more, and IT STILL KEEPS COMING BACK FOR MORE!This is definitely a "shut your brain off at the start" kind of movie, and even kind of good for a first time viewing, if all you're out for is some kind of cheap, dumbed down quick thrill, but if you're like me, and like your movies to be a little bit more cerebral and challenging, then you may wanna skip this one. I sure wish I did! Thank you. :>)

reviewText: Orphan (Jaume Collet-Serra, 2009)To Orphan's credit, I will say that the assertion made in the trailer is accurate: I never saw the Big Reveal coming. The flipside of that is that I didn't see it coming because it's a huge cop-out, as it is with most films of this type. This is a problem, because in order to explain what's wrong with this movie, I'd have to give away the big reveal, and I do try not to do spoilers in a review--especially when I'm going to end up telling you to see the movie, as I probably will with this one. There are a number of good things about this movie, and the fact that they're each balanced with a bad aspect doesn't make the good parts any less rewarding. But it's the Big Reveal that was the killer here; I'd have unhesitatingly recommended the movie, warts and all, were it not for that.Orphan is the story of a family who adopt a nine-year-old girl named Esther, played quite creepily by Hounddog's Isabelle Fuhrman in her first big-budget flick. Previous to Esther's arrival, the family--mother Kate (The Manchurian Candidate's Vera Farmiga), father John (The Mysteries of Pittsburgh's Peter Sarsgaard), son Daniel (Star Trek's Jimmy Bennett), and Daughter Max (Aryanna Engineer in her first screen role)--is your basic family, though they have recently (it's never explicitly stated, but is seems to have been roughly six months before this) had a devastating event. The couple's third child, Jessica, was stillborn, and they're looking for a child to whom they can give the love, in Kate's words, they had for Jessica. When they first meet Esther, at the St. Mary's Home for Girls, she seems bright, open, and friendly, and Sister Abigail (the wonderful CCH Pounder) is actually kind of impressed that the usually reserved Esther has opened up to them. When they get her home, though, things start going wrong. While John is convinced it's all in her head, Kate thinks that perhaps Esther is not the innocent she passes herself off as (and thanks to the way the story unfolds, we know that Kate is right, and that the big thing here is Kate needing to convince John that she's not crazy).I think a lot of the problem Orphan has had with early reviewers has to do with its marketing; this is not a horror film in any way, it's a bad-kid movie along the lines of The Good Son or Godsend, a psychological thriller rather than a horror flick. It doesn't help that Dark Castle's name is attached to it, but somewhere along the way, Dark Castle has graduated from being a purveyor of crappy remakes to a distributor of movies that are actually trying, and the first few scenes here definitely try. Check out the shot at the beginning of the third scene in, where Vera Farmiga is walking across a schoolyard. The optical illusion as she walks just along the tree branch's path is just great. Not at all the kind of thing I'd have expected from Collet-Serra (House of Wax). Looked at as a thriller, it's not as much of a disconnect. And the acting here is top-notch from everyone involved, which makes it a great deal stronger than other movies of this type. There's quite a bit to like here.Balancing that, though, are the movie's problems, all of which come from a screenplay by first-time write David Johnson, formerly a production assistant to Frank Darabont. For a movie that essentially revolves around this family's dynamic and how it changes in Esther's presence, we don't actually get to see much of that family dynamic; it suffers from the American problem of thinking that too much character development is a bad thing, and so we get told a lot of things we should be shown, and a lot of things that would probably have helped make this a great movie (one of the biggest is the character of John's mother, who we see as nothing more than a way to advance the plot; there's a scene she has with Vera Farmiga that tells us, though, she could have been so much more). And, of course, there's a Big Reveal, which seems to exist as a way for the screenwriter to assuage his conscience about making a bad-kid movie (compare, for example, to Godsend, where the cop-out wasn't so much in the Big Reveal as it was scattered throughout the movie). More subtly, though, I think the bond formed between Esther and Max would have been a lot more believable if Esther's personality hadn't been so simplistic. We know from the opening scenes that Esther is capable of acting friendly; wouldn't it have been obvious to have Esther build a strong friendship with Max in order to secure her trust, instead of doing what she does? (It got so bad I really thought the Big Reveal was going to be that she was a pint-sized hitman for the Russian Mob.) Contrasted with all this is the script's willingness to allow us to get to know these characters, which is something of a contradiction in terms; I wonder if a lot of the problems with this didn't happen in the editing room rather than in the script. Perhaps they cut it because they thought it was too long (the theatrical cut runs just over two hours); I'd have been more than willing to sit through another thirty or forty-five minutes of the slow, but wonderful, setup here in order to see more of the family and the way it changes before we get to the nasty stuff. And for the record, the nasty stuff isn't all that nasty (the movie's opening scene is actually its most gruesome).This movie stirred up controversy months before it opened, which telegraphs to me that, obviously, those stirring didn't actually see the movie. I don't think I'll be wrong in my prediction that few of them, if any, will ever actually see it; movie protesters rarely do (I quizzed protesters outside movies from The Last Temptation of Christ to Kinsey, and have yet to find one who actually saw the movie they were complaining about). Ignore them. While Orphan has its share of problems, as far as bad-kid movies go, it's the best I've come across. At this rate, we should finally get the definitive bad-kid psychological thriller in about ten years. I'll be waiting. **

reviewText: This is the third time this movie has been remade.  The original was made in 1956 called The Bad Seed.  It was about this 11-year-old girl who, although looked cute and innocent with those blonde pigtails, was really in fact evil.  I watched snippets of the film and didn't find it scary at all.  Then in 1993 there was "The Good Son", starring Macaulay Culkin and Elijah Wood.  Henry (played by Culkin) appears to be the good son, but Mark (Wood) sees his true colours.  This movie scared me.  Macaulay Culkin's performance is phenomenal; a 10, no question.  Now Orphan (2009) takes a different approach.  Here you have a 9-year-old girl named Esther. reviewText: You just can't take "Orphan" too seriously. From the lengthy (and "bloody") opening sequence to the jaw-dropping finale, the story of this "bad seed" horror film directed Jaume Collet-Serra (remake version of "House of Wax") remains preposterous. That doesn't mean "Orphan" is not worth watching, however. The film is fairly entertaining as long as you can ignore the obvious plot holes, graphic violence and, well, the "twist" that will leave most viewers speechless.Esther (Isabelle Fuhrman) is a 9-year-old orphaned Russian girl. Sociable and charming, Esther is adopted by John Coleman (Peter Sarsgaard) and his wife Kate Coleman (Vera Farmiga) who has lost her baby recently. At first everything goes well and John and Kate are both very happy until one day Kate starts to feel that something is not quite right about Esther, a girl with a serene smile."Orphan" is largely well-acted (Isabelle Fuhrman as enigmatic Esther is quite impressive), but it takes too much time for the film to get things moving. Also, several episodes make the characters look very stupid - if someone claims that his child, severely wounded, is "pushed" by my child, I would take the matter much seriously than the Colemans.But what is most disappointing is that Jaume Collet-Serra has missed so many chances to make the film a better thriller. There is a scene where Esther shows her sexual side, but that aspect of the storyline is not fully explored. John and Kate Coleman have two children, 12-year-old Daniel (Jimmy Bennett) and very adorable Max (Aryana Engineer), but their presence in the story as unprotected family member doesn't really enhance the suspense. Maybe I am wrong, but somehow the Spanish-born director Jaume Collet-Serra is forced to pull punches where he knows he shouldn't.
summary: "There Is Something Wrong with Esther" ... and the Movie Itself: Good, Not Great
